source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: Zircaloy-4, used extensively as a cladding and core structural material in water-cooled nuclear reactors, is a zirconium-based alloy containing small additions of tin, iron, and chromium
composition_raw: zirconium-based alloy containing small additions of tin, iron, and chromium

extra_properties.aging_effect: dissolution of metastable Zr₄(Fe,Cr) and formation of stable Zr(Fe,Cr)₂

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk1
evidence_span: Phase instabilities detected by transmission electron microscopy after irradiation include disappearance of the metastable precipitate
composition_raw: zirconium-based alloy containing small additions of tin, iron, and chromium

extra_properties.microstructure: single-phase solid solution maintained to high fluences
extra_properties.precipitate_decomposition: Zr(Fe,Cr)₂ loses crystalline structure, becomes amorphous

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk1

extra_properties.precipitation: iron precipitates at grain boundaries as Zeta-phase

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: Figure 1 is a low magnification picture of the lamellar cells formed in as-quenched Zircaloy-4

extra_properties.phase_transformation: α-phase nucleated at β-phase grain boundaries

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: Figure 2 shows that the growth direction of the lamellae is along the c direction

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: Rearrangement of dislocations by forming polygonized networks or sub-boundaries and twins within the lamellar matrix occurred during aging at 560°C

extra_properties.microstructural_changes: dislocation rearrangement, precipitate dissolution, new precipitation
extra_properties.precipitate_composition: equal amounts of iron and chromium

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: Polygonized dislocation networks and small cells were developed during the early stage of the aging at 650°C

extra_properties.transformation: cell structures developed into new small grains
extra_properties.heterogeneity: original lamellar structures remained in some regions

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk4
evidence_span: Results of Neutron Irradiation

extra_properties.irradiation_testing: mentioned but no specific data provided

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk5
evidence_span: Consistent with the previous reports [1,7], $Z _ { \Gamma _ { 4 } } ( \mathrm { F e } , \mathrm { C r } )$ precipitates formed during quenching from the $\beta$ -phase disappeared completely upon irradiation at $2 8 8 \mathrm { ‰}$ There were no new precipitates visible to a fluence of $1 4 . 7 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { ~ n / m } ^ { 2 }$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: The transition of metastable Zr₊(Fe,Cr) to stable Zr(Fe,Cr) involves the process of apparent dissolution of Zr₄(Fe,Cr) and the process of precipitation of Zr(Fe,Cr)₂ as revealed by aging at 560°C

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: The transition processes are moderately fast at 650°C

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: The transition processes are very sudden at 750°C. The annihilation of lamellar interface boundaries and the nucleation of Zr(Fe,Cr)₂ at 750°C seem to be assisted by the annealing-out of supersaturated vacancies

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: The observation of the coexistence of cubic (C15) and hexagonal (C14) Zr(Fe,Cr)₂ after aging at 750°C

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: As annealing time is prolonged, only hexagonal Zr(Fe,Cr)₂ is stable

extra_properties.phase_stability: hexagonal phase stable after prolonged aging

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: Microhardness results show the generally expected decrease in hardness as the microstructure is altered... it does appear that an increment in solution hardening is measured for the specimens annealed for very short times at 560 and 650°C

extra_properties.solution_hardening: increment observed for short annealing times

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: The corrosion results indicate that in beta-quenched Zircaloy-4, details of the precipitate and dislocation structure do not strongly influence nodular corrosion

extra_properties.nodular_corrosion_influence: precipitate and dislocation structure do not strongly influence

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk7
evidence_span: The microstructures of Zircaloy-4 in the as-β-quenched condition consist of an α-lamellar matrix and iron-rich Zr₄(Fe,Cr) precipitates at lamellar boundaries

extra_properties.microstructure: α-lamellar matrix with Zr₄(Fe,Cr) precipitates at lamellar boundaries
extra_properties.dislocation_types: both a and c type dislocations

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk7
evidence_span: Upon aging in the α-phase field temperatures, the processes of dissolution of the Zr₄(Fe,Cr) precipitates, annihilation of the interface dislocation networks, and formation of stable Zr(Fe,Cr)₂ precipitates occur in sequence

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk7
evidence_span: During aging at 750°C, the just described processes proceed very rapidly

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk7
evidence_span: The Zr(Fe.Cr)₂ precipitates formed during short-time aging at 750‰ have two crystal structures, C15 cubic as the major structure and C14 hexagonal-close-packed as the minor structure

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk7
evidence_span: As aging time is increased, only the hexagonal Zr(Fe,Cr)₂ is stable

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk7
evidence_span: Complete disappearance of the Zr₄(Fe,Cr) precipitates occurs in β quenched Zircaloy4 during irradiation

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk7
evidence_span: A single-phase solid solution is apparently achieved and is maintained to high fluence without new visible precipitation and segregation

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk7
evidence_span: Postirradiation annealing of β quenched Zircaloy-4 at 560°C results in nucleation of Zr-Fe Zeta phase at grain boundaries

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk7
evidence_span: The irradiation-induced c dislocations are not affected by the postirradiation annealing at 560°C

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk7
evidence_span: Postirradiation annealing of β·quenched Zircaloy4 at 750°C results in annihilation of dislocation networks and nucleation of Zr(Fe,Cr)₂ precipitates at boundaries

microstructural_changes: nucleation of Zr(Fe,Cr)₂ precipitates at boundaries

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk7
evidence_span: uniform corrosion was enhanced in welded areas, but nodular corrosion was rarely observed

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk7
evidence_span: The welds used in the current study were greyish in color and the uniform oxide thickness exceeded 30 μm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk7
evidence_span: Nodular corrosion resistance in high temperature steam does not appear to be strongly influenced by the types of precipitates present after the various test conditions of the study

corrosion_data.nodular_corrosion_resistance: not strongly influenced by precipitate types

extra_properties.precipitate_influence: nodular corrosion resistance not strongly influenced

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk8
evidence_span: Zr-1wt%Nb fuel sheathing contained Zr(FeCr): Laves phase precipitates with either the C-14 hexagonal or C-15 cubic structure

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk8
evidence_span: Orthorhombic Zr₃Fe precipitates were also tentatively identified

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_031_chunk8
evidence_span: Tetragonal Zr₂Fe precipitates were found in Zr-2.5wt%Nb pressure tubing containing 700-ppm iron

evidence_span: Zr(FeCr): precipitates in Zr-1wt%Nb fuel sheathing

extra_properties.comparative_volume_fraction: much larger than Zr₂Fe in Zr-2.5wt%Nb
